awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity: Building Capacity of Women in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
The Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program (HSI Program) aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education and build capacity at HSIs. Projects supported by the HSI Program will also generate new knowledge about how to achieve these aims.  This project at Mount Saint Mary's University will advance the aims of the HSI Program by increasing retention in STEM, and preparing students for research and other opportunities in STEM.  Through this project, Mount Saint Mary's University aims to improve the quality of STEM education for its undergraduate students, the majority of whom are Hispanic women. The purpose of this project is three-fold: 1) increase student interest, motivation, and retention in STEM; 2) prepare students for external research opportunities, internships, and future employment opportunities in STEM; and 3) increase student interest in conducting STEM research and attending graduate school. Aligned with this purpose, the project seeks to achieve four outcomes: 1) increased satisfactory completion of undergraduate STEM major courses; 2) increased undergraduate student retention in STEM majors; 3) increased undergraduate participation in research; and 4) increases in the number of STEM graduates who enter graduate school or are employed in STEM fields. By increasing women and Hispanic representation in graduate school and the STEM workforce, the project can contribute to increased diversity and equity in STEM fields. 

The project plans to improve undergraduate STEM education by: 1) revising biology, chemistry, and mathematics courses; 2) providing academic support for students in STEM major courses; 3) offering summer programs that prepare students for collegiate STEM courses and future research opportunities; 4) providing students with peer and faculty mentoring support; and 5) supporting research and internship experiences. The University will specifically examine the effect that peer mentoring has on student retention. Although peer mentoring has been examined by other researchers, this project's unique combination of women and Hispanic students, and multi-year mentoring will provide important new information.   Both qualitative and quantitative data will be collected. The project will determine the extent to which the participants met the project goals as well as operational objectives. The program will add to the body of knowledge on best practices to engage undergraduate STEM students at both Hispanic-serving institutions and institutions that have large populations of female students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the National Science Foundation’s Building Capacity of Women in STEM Program at Mount Saint Mary’s University (MSMU) was to improve and enhance the quality of STEM education provided to MSMU’s traditional undergraduate students, the majority of whom are Hispanic and all of whom are women; and to increase the number and percentage of students who successfully complete STEM degrees and becoming employed in Los Angeles’s strong STEM economy. This grant sought to achieve this goal through five main grant activities: 1) major curriculum revisions in gateway courses; 2) increase academic support through supplemental instruction programs for major courses; 3) build and implement summer programs that prepare students for collegiate STEM courses and future research opportunities; 4) formalize peer and faculty mentoring support programs; and 5) increase research and internship support throughout the entire year.

 

During the course of the six-year period, the project achieved the following project outcomes:

1. Increasing the percentage of students satisfactorily completing STEM major courses that were previously a significant barrier to success. For the first year STEM courses, pass rates at the end of that first year increased from 70% to 90% for Biology, from 52% to 86% for Chemistry and from 57% to 60% for the academic year Calculus with summer Calculus offering rising up to up to 90%. Molecular Biology, an upper-division keystone course for STEM majors, pass rates rose from 78% to 92% by the end of the grant.

2. Increasing STEM student retention within STEM majors. Retention increased from 59% prior to the grant activities to 86.2% by the end of the grant. Further, all students retained did not switch to other majors.

3. Increasing the number of STEM students participating in research on campus and through summer internship. Participation increased from an average of about 10% over the summer to 32% by the end of the grant. Further, of those students participating in summer research, 68% were first-generation college students. Over 90% felt that the experience helped them in with success in their major and their career path, as well as increasing confidence and a sense of belonging in their STEM major. Of the skills that students felt were improved through summer research, ‘problem solving/critical thinking skills’ ranked the highest, at 94%.

Some key impacts of this project include institutionalizing formal STEM curricular and student support structures that now span across multiple areas of the university, including student support centers and within the STEM departments. Course revisions enabled cross-content, with intersectional modules that reinforced multi-disciplinary STEM concepts needed for success. These modules were embedded in our shared learning management system for all STEM instructors to continue to use and build upon in the future. Further, this project specifically provides a road map for the creation of successful ‘in-house’ support structures at Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI’s), including student-led Peer Mentor programs, the creation of a Lab Skills program during the academic year to help improve skills in a ‘low stress’ environment, and the insertion of summer research into the culture of the STEM majors. 

In a broader sense, this project increased educational and workforce access in order to open pathways for economic development to low-income and underserved families and communities. Our focus on inclusion and belonging in our programs and curriculum furthered the psychosocial well-being of our students who have been traditionally marginalized by systemic racism. Within the STEM community, we have been actively engaged in empowering the voices and contributions of all non-dominant races, identities and socioeconomic backgrounds for the betterment of all.


Last Modified: 12/20/2024
Modified by: Jennifer Chotiner
